comment: Constantly makes mistakes in his own lessons which give you the wrong answers once calculated. There's no telling what answers are correct on quizzes and tests because his own mistakes (transposing numbers, forgetting numbers) calculate out differently. Avoid like the plague.

FIN4220 is a very difficult course in general. While I received a C and had my fair share of struggles, Professor Ramirez did a wonderful job of helping me. I was in constant communication with him this semester and that allowed for better understanding of course materials. Just speak with him, do the work, and ask for help when needed!
DO NOT TAKE HIS CLASS. I REPEAT, DO NOT TAKE HIS CLASS.

I enjoyed his class. He grades how he says he does. He is very easy going with partial credit. If you just write down an answer you will get it wrong, and he tells you that everyday from day 1. Just show up to class and actually listen and write down what he says. If you do that you will do fine in the class. He also gives lots of extra credit.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--Clear grading criteria

comment: I gave Ramirez a shot despite the comments that were left on here and the ones that float around campus.  I thought what the heck, how hard could it be? I was wrong. Read the comments, they're accurate, from the course difficulty to his teaching style. My suggestion, if it's your last semester, do yourself a favor and go with a different professor.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Participation matters--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: I thought ramirez was cool until he kept disappearing going to conferences. How are you gone for two weeks, come back a class before the test, give the review, and expect to know the material. It was to the point that older adults were getting frustrated with this professor.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Skip class? You won't pass.--TEST HEAVY

comment: Prof Ramirez is a tough one to rate. He really wants everyone to succeed, but he makes you work for it. He teaches the process, not formulas. Pay attention in class and study the practice sets. If you are truly interested in learning I would recommend him. Grade is based only on tests. Hard course; I learned more in this FIN class than any others.

He is a hard one to rate. If you want to be an investment banker I would say all three classes are mandatory because he is the only professor that is going to go this in depth into the field. That being said he is a jumbled lecturer, and a lot of mistakes in his materials. I like him though. Frustrating but worth it, for serious students only.
My finance course was jumbled and confusing.  Can't say that I gained anything from this.  If you want to learn finance, look somewhere else.

Im an accounting major and I took this class as an elective. After the first test I thought this was a big mistake. But I kept with it and ended up doing well in the class. It is a hard class but ramirez does a good job explaining and gives you all the resources you need to learn the material. Its a lot of work but I learned a lot in the class.

Take this class if you are interested in learning Finance! I am currently in the Investment Banking field and he tries to prepare students to think in concepts, not formulas. His poor rating on here is a reflection of lazy, unmotivated, students who are going nowhere. If you are looking for an easy A for 3100 for non-finance majors then stay away.

DO NOT TAKE THIS GUY. I cannot stress that enough. He gets confused by his own examples in class and becomes furious if you try to help him. He has weird mood swings, do not ask a question when he is in a mood. The only way to do well on the tests is to do the practice sets that he posts. Reading the book and taking notes in class will not help.

Avoid taking him if you can. Worst professor I've ever had. Weird grading scheme, useless lectures, and most students drop his class. He gets offended when people ask questions and says they should already know the answer.

Professor Ramirez takes a bad wrap because he actually wants students to learn. Willing to help when it is needed. No need to buy textbook. Attendance is taken. DO THE PRACTICE SETS... extremely helpful.

I had this prof in a grad level course.  Sounds similar now.  The class: confusing & irrelevant for most.  I have worked in Corp Fin for a Fortune 500 as an Exec - never once did the convoluted theories apply in real-world situations.  Beware..assignments included requirements for unpublished financial data (costs thousands of dollars to purchase).
Will not teach introduction  to finance as an introductory course. When you ask a question he responds by saying you should know the material.
Don't Take....he is terrible....hard and completely in his own world.  Strange grading sceme and don't ever take in a minimester.  Assigns impossible assignments.

I hate this teacher!! Worst teacher ever!!! Even with his curve on the last test 25 out of the 30 students left in the class failed. He lectures about nothing waste of time to go to class but he takes attendence! You have to teach your self. The exams are only 15 questions and the questions are worth 5 to 65 points each. I'm a straight A student an
He is the worst professor I ever had. Very confusing and focusing unnecessary items more. Stay away if you can.

Probably one of the worst teachers I have ever had.  Very hard to understand, very confusing...just not a good teacher.  He told me that since I was not understanding the material, which he thought was easy to understand, I needed to be tested for a learning disability.  You HAVE to teach yourself, go to class, read the book, and go to class.

Ramirez is not a very good professor. He teaches the class like it is Graduate school and his 15% curve is not exactly a curve because he just makes everything to worth more points!!! Stay away from him unless you know the material.

Worst teacher ever!!! So hard, teaches on graduate level... and it is really supposed to be an intro to finance. not available for questions before or after class, gets very offended when students ask questions... definitely do not recommend him.

His first exam is the easiest...so score as high as you can. In general, he wants you to succeed so he tries really hard...yet most of the class did poorly on his exams. I feel his notes were too confusing. Basically, if you want to succeed in his class read the book and do the homework. He has a 15% curve at the end of semester which really helps.
